Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2008 03:08PM Nanstoys wrote: Don't know if I will be using Aquaphor or not. Nurse said I will be leaving with a care package after my first treatment.
Posts.Title: March 2008 Rads Team brst26 juliajo

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2008 07:10AM Nanstoys wrote: Hey girls, sorry you are down, but I really understand.  Am lucky didn't have Chemo and doing the rads is scary.  Another step into the great unknown, and no one knows how you will react to any step of the process.  So far so good.  Had my third one yesterday and am tired.  A little redness and swelling and a warm feeling.  Meet with my doctor today to go over my progress and disability papers.  Keep the faith ladies, we will make it through together!  On a side note my mom used to say that she was sick and tired of being sick and tired.  I finally know what she meant. I had a DCIS that was small and have had surgery and rads, and sometimes I feel that I shouldn't even be on this site, but darn it my cancer was and is very scary to me even if it is not a bad as others.  Sorry just venting.
Posts.Title: March 2008 Rads Team brst26 juliajo

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2008 08:20AM Nanstoys wrote: Well I start today, my first treatment is at 3:15. Don't know yet if I will come back to work or not.  According to my rad nurse they take the x-rays once a week just to double check and make sure that they are in the correct treatment field.  If you lose or gain weight it could move the tats and they might have to readjust.  My rad was very insistant on the not shaving and no deoderant. I do have some Toms of Maine natural deoderant which according so some literature is ok becuase it does not contain allumiun (spelling) salts which can react during the radiation.  Those looking for cotton bras I found some at Walmart for $6.00.  All cotton and snap in the front.  I got them 2 sizes larger then my usual so they have larger sizes.  I also found some all cotton sports bras that pull over but have really lose elastic on the bottom for 3 for $9.00 and men's Hanes t-shirts a package of 5 for $8.00.
Posts.Title: March 2008 Rads Team brst26 juliajo

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2008 12:29PM Nanstoys wrote: Thanks for all of the information.  I am planning on exercising during my radiation treatment as much as I can.  I am a swimmer so will have to change up my routine.  My gym actually has a cancer treatment work out program that I am joining. It is twice a week for the duration of your treatment and they waive your dues for that time period.  I hope to work, but if it gets to be too much I will go out on short term disability. The corn starch sounds good and will check with my nurse about the cream.  I am large busted so going without a bra if I am working is not an option. I am hoping to have enough energy to play with the dogs even if I can't run with them. (one Great Dane and one Gordon Setter/Shelti cross)They are what is helping me through each day.  You can't feel too sorry for yourself when you have a great big dog try to crawl in lap with his big blue toy and giving you kisses to make you feel better.  He just knows if he lays down beside me that I will feel better, and he is right.  Boyfriend and family also wonderful.
Posts.Title: March 2008 Rads Team brst26 juliajo

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2008 02:39PM Nanstoys wrote: I heard from my rad onc office that I should start treatment this week, just waiting for my doc to approve the plan. When I heard I would be starting I got butterflies, strange because I thought that I was ok with it.  Anyway, when I met with my doc and the nurse they gave me pages of what I could and could not do.  No swimming too drying, no lotions or soap 4 hours prior to my treatment.  No deodorant except Tom's of Maine (can buy on line), even then not 4 hours before treatment.  Soft cotton bras, T-shirts or cami's, no blends or poly as that will make you sweat and can irritate.  I have heard that you can get the cotton bras at Wal-Mart and at Kohl's although I was not able to find them on line.  JC Penny has a nice front zip sports bra that is mostly cotton and not too expensive, I ordered mine on line. Bras should be at least one size larger due to swelling.  No shaving while having treatment and then for a month after use an electric razor.  Wash anything next to your skin with Delph or Ivory, no fabric softener, no dryer sheets. No soap that has any additives in it.  No nylon bath scrubbers.  I am still checking on soap and the nurse told me that she is looking also to find a good one for me.  They prefer that you not use it at all if poss., but just run luke warm water over.  No hot tubs, sauna or high heat or sun exposure.  The high heat can react with the radiation making it even hotter and causing a worse skin reaction.  Cold can also over act and cause a reaction.  Drink tons of water; eat fresh fruits and veggies, high protein, low fat.  No processed foods or mixes (cut out the hamburger helper and Rice a roni, ha, ha) no alcohol. Low salt, no soy.  No caffeine.  You need to stay as well hydrated as poss., and avoid anything that may dehydrate you.  The doc and nurse both say that really helps.  Walk at least 30 minutes a day and get fresh air, do deep breathing, and make sure to stretch as much as possible.  Avoid crowds and people with colds.  I had a party yesterday and told all the little nieces and nephews that I would see them soon.  Love them all, the little germ carriers.  So that is what I have heard from my rad team.  I will meet with the doctor once a week and with the nurse everyday prior to treatment so she can asses my skin.  They will give me lotions etc to use.  By the way when I am nervous I talk a lot. LOL
Posts.Title: March 2008 Rads Team brst26 juliajo

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2008 06:18PM Nanstoys wrote: Sharona, The nurse went over with me do's and don'ts.  Here they are and hope they help.  No deordant on the side being treated, wash with only Ivory soap using luke warm water and be very gentel.  Pat the area dry do not rub as it can break down the skin.  They gave me Aveeno to use twice a day, once directly after my treatment and then again before bed.  Use nothing on your breast 4 hours prior to treatment.  NO underwire bras, soft cotton is best (I found some at Target, nursing bras, at least one size larger than usual)  your breast will swell and feel tender including your nipple.  Let your nurse know if your nipple begins to bother you and they can give you something to treat it.  Your skin can turn anything from tan to bright red.  You can have blistering, tearing and weeping, but not everyone does. No shaving under that arm (I may have to braid mine).  She did tell me that I will have to give up wearing a bra and go to a cami by about the 4th week and may even go to just t-shirts.  Needless to say I will be taking time off work, that would be just too much information to share with my work group.  The whole idea is to try to keep anything from rubbing on your skin.  She told me if the Aveeno is not working to let her know and they will give me other creams to help.  No heating pads, ice packs, electric blankets, hot tubs. swimming, tan booths or sunbathing.  She said to drink tons of water and eat fruits, vegs and lean protein. To have yogurt, milk and cheese.  Stay away from processed foods.  Hope that helps some.
Posts.Title: March 2008 Rads Team brst26 juliajo

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2008 10:07AM Nanstoys wrote: Sharona - sorry, how is your son doing? Hope all is well.
Posts.Title: March 2008 Rads Team brst26 juliajo

Posts.Content: May 9, 2008 03:11PM Nanstoys wrote: Finished my treatments yesterday.  Altogether not a bad experience.  Some fatigue by the end of the week and some blistering (very little under the breast and under my arm), but very manageble.  I was told that the radiation stays in your system about a month, the skin irratation and the fatigue will gradually go away. I can start swimming again in a month.  Have kept up with my exercise and feel good for the most part. (I have 2 Great Danes so exercise is mandatory at our house)  Glad this done and ready to get on with the rest of my life.  Thanks for all the support, the best to all of you. Nan
Posts.Title: March 2008 Rads Team brst26 juliajo

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2008 01:54PM - edited Mar 13, 2008 01:55PM by Nanstoys Well I had my simulation today and it was pretty easy except it brings into focus that is a reality.  More of an emotional then a physical toll today. Each appointment will take about an hour all together expect on Tuesdays which will be longer because I need to meet with the doctor and get an full exam.  I will have blood tests every week to keep track of my red and white cells etc.   I start on Monday at 3:15 and then we will see how it goes from there. Thanks all for the support.  Sharona, I understand the depression.  I have always been the strong one and find my self getting up in the middle of the night and crying a few tears.  I have my dogs that come out and sit with me and my wonderful partner, Michael, of 16 years that wakes up and rubs my back, then we all go back to bed for a couple of hours.  I actually have found myself snapping at simple questions.  My PCP offered me meds and I may take her up on them for a least the first week.  Reena, thanks for the information on the fatigue, I have short term disability so I may take it.  I was going to try not too as we have a big office move and new clinics coming on line but don't know if I can do it all.  Don't tell anyone I said that.  Ok my whine session is over.  Thanks.
Posts.Title: March 2008 Rads Team brst26 juliajo

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2008 02:39PM Nanstoys wrote: Well ladies, count me in.  I was diagnosised in Jan with DCIS, had a lumpectomy on 1/21 have changed oncologists, the first onoclogist initally said, I need do nothing additional I had a small tumor, 3 mm and 2 mm of clear margin.  I skipped home.  Then I got a call from the surgeon wanting to schedule another surgery.  HUMMMM Went back to the onoclogist who when 180 and said, surgery, chemo, radiation and Armidex. Went to surgeon who said, you don't need surgery just radiation.  HUMMMM  Went and a second opinion.  Best thing I did.  New onoclogist - went step by step through my pathology report with me.  Gave me the down and dirty.  No additonal surgery but yes to radiation.  NO Armidex as my tumor was too small to test, so unsure if it was pos or neg.  Anyway had my mapping and simulation down on Thursday and will start on or around St. Patricks Day. I have a great group of professionals around and a support group that is great.  Trina- I'm with you.  I am 56 and feel that I am too young for this. Well ladies it is All for one and one for all. I am determined to live my life to follow my favorite quote "Life in a banquet and most poor suckers are starving to death"  Mame Dennis
Posts.Title: March 2008 Rads Team brst26 juliajo

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2008 09:20AM Nanstoys wrote: I go in Thursday for another simulation study at 12:15 - not sure how long it will take My regular schedule will start on Monday 3/17 and my time slot is 3:15.  I will find out on Thursday a better idea of time involved.  At this point I am sure I need to be there by 3 to get ready etc.  I am not sure how long everything will take or how I will feel following treatment.   I have those damned butterflies in my stomach again.
Posts.Title: March 2008 Rads Team brst26 juliajo

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2008 12:55PM Nanstoys wrote: I will actually start my rads today.  Was scheduled to start on Monday but had to rush to Idaho as my cousin who was coming to stay with me during my treatment had a massive heart attack on his way to Colorado. I managed to make it to his bedside and was with him for about 3 hours before he passed away. After making all of the arrangements and having him cremated there,  I have brought his ashes home with me and will have a memorial for him in Oregon in April on his birthday.  Still working but will see how I feel.  Am already fatigued by just life at this point.
Posts.Title: March 2008 Rads Team brst26 juliajo

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2008 10:06AM Nanstoys wrote: Thank you all for your sympathy.  Just one more hurdle to overcome.  One treatment down 36 to go.  I am so tired today I could just lay my head down on my desk and sleep. The company frowns on that however.  Treatment went fine, I am a little red, a little sore today and swollen.  Trina - I got a blood test prior to starting as well as a chest x-ray and an EKG - my rad onc said I will have the blood work every one to two weeks depending on how I feel.  But at least every two weeks. Sharona - I will meet with my rad onc every Tuesday to discuss my progress and my general health etc.  I am surprised that you aren't scheduled to meet with them.  I'd stop at the front desk and at least set up an appointment. I will talk to the nurse either before or after my treatment everyday.  They were great yesterday making sure everything was ok and making sure I remembered all the "rules". Larousse - I live out in the county and take 40 minutes or so over back roads to get to and from work, so my doctor is taking that into consideration when putting me on disability.    There is no such thing as public transportation or car pooling where we are, which is why we love it.  I also have no stop gap disability, so can not work 1/2 days I am either here 40 hours or on disability.
Posts.Title: March 2008 Rads Team brst26 juliajo

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2008 09:22AM Nanstoys wrote: No nausa but not hungry at all.  Had my third treatment yesterday afternoon and by the time I drove the 40 minutes home was ready for bed.  Fixed dinner for Mike and kept him company while he ate.  Played with the dogs and made myself stay up until 9.  This needing to have at least 8 hours sleep is disconcerning for me.  I have never slept more then 6 hours at any time.  I used to get by with 4.
Posts.Title: Nausea during radiation?? mimi1 lizzie5308

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2008 11:17PM Nanstoys wrote: What you may be feeling is scar tissue which can feel like another lump, especially if it is in the biospy area.  I agree with Meryl call your Breast Center or your surgeon.  There is no sense losing sleep if someone can put your concerns to rest.  Let us know what happens.

Posts.Title: No wire bras JoniB Binney4

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2008 09:18AM Nanstoys wrote: Hang in there.  You have a very caring PCP.  A breast MRI is the latest and greatest. This way you won't have to wait 6 months, you'll know soon after the MRI. The rad was prob. correct but your doctor wants to error on the side of caution.  Any other family members besides your cousin who have been diagnosised with BC?  One thing please make sure that your MRI is authorized by your insurnace company. Having the authorization will make life much easier down the road.  Also you should get a copy of the rad report and start a medical file for yourself.
Posts.Title: Not sure what this means.... connorsmommy Nanstoys

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2008 02:56PM Nanstoys wrote: Call your sugeon and speak to the nurse.  You may have developed a hematoma (blood pooling) and they may want to see to check it out.  Have never heard of a bee stinging sensation. Everyone is different.  I am 6 weeks out and mine stopped really hurting in about 5 days.  I do get the itichy feeling  because it is healing inside, and I can feel the scar tissue, but I would call and check with the surgeon.
Posts.Title: hard lumps post lumpectomy anniee Kimber

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2008 05:02PM Nanstoys wrote: I would go for a second opinion from another oncologist. I did and was very happy.  My initial oncologist and surgeon were at odds on my treatment, found a wonderful onoclogist who really talked to me and outlined my treatment.  Am having radiation as I had a very small DCIS, 3 mm with 2 mm clean margins.  My lumpectomy was 1/21 and my radiation starts St. Patricks Day.  The luck of the Irish.  I feel bad posting as I have been lucky and my cancer was caught early, is not aggressive, and didn't have to have my breast removed.  Actually everyone was in favor of a lumpectomy.
